text: {| |} SS Miraflores was a freighter lost on 19 February 1942. The ship left New Orleans on 6 February 1942 with a crew of 34 and made an intermediate stop in Haiti before sailing for New York on 14 February 1942.Ludington Daily News, Ludington, Michigan, June 16, 1942, "Six Ships are Sunk", page 1 Miraflores was owned by the Standard Fruit and Steamship Company.Berkeley Daily Gazette, Berkeley, California, 15 June 1942, page 2, " New Ship Mystery Rivals Case of Cyclops" She had a gross tonnage of 2,158 and was 270 feet long.Gettysburg Times, Gettysburg, Pa., 16 June 1942, page 6, "Atlantic Ship Toll Now at 271" She was built in England in 1921 and was engaged in transporting bananas between Central America and New Orleans.The Daily Independent, Murphysboro, Illinois, "Another Cyclops Mystery May Be in The Making", page 5 Miraflores was torpedoed and sunk in the Atlantic Ocean north east of Delaware Capes, United States by U-432 with the loss of all 34 crew."Miraflores". Uboat. Retrieved 21 January 2017 The ship was later discovered and identified in 2007. == References == == External links == * * * Category:1942 in Virginia Category:Maritime incidents in February 1942 Category:Shipwrecks of the Virginia coast Category:1921 ships Category:World War II merchant ships of the United Kingdom Category:Ships built on the River Tyne Category:Ships sunk by German submarines in World War II Category:Steamships of the United Kingdom Category:World War II shipwrecks in the Atlantic Ocean
title: SS Miraflores
